metadata.case_name: Dhanrajamal Gobindram v. Shamji Kalidas & Co.

facts.text: On October 24, 1957, buyers (Dhanrajamal Gobindram) entered into an agreement with sellers (Shamji Kalidas & Co.) for purchase of 500 bales of African raw cotton (ARBP 52 F.A.Q. Crop/58) at Rs. 1401 nett per candy CIF Bombay, shipment February/March 1958, subject to Bye-laws of East India Cotton Association Ltd. Bombay except bye-law 35, and clause requiring buyers to obtain import licence by February 20, 1958.
By letter dated November 30, 1957, contract amended to confirm carry over of contracted goods for two months (March and April) if necessary, with buyers to pay carry over charges at Mombasa rate.

Contract not performed. Sellers wrote five letters between March 1, 1958, and May 26, 1958. Buyers replied on June 3, 1958, stating contract void and illegal, rejecting debit note for Rs. 34,103.15 nP. arising from carry forward and re-sale.
Sellers invoked arbitration clause and Bye-law 38-A, filed petition under s.20 Indian Arbitration Act in Bombay High Court Original Side to file agreement and refer dispute to arbitration.

Buyers resisted petition by affidavits: first (July 31, 1958) claiming cls.6 and 7 unlawful under import policy and Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947; second (Feb 4, 1959) vagueness of 'usual Force Majeure Clause'; third (Feb 27, 1959) amendment letter void.
K.T. Desai J. (March 3, 1959) dismissed petition as not maintainable, dispute on validity to be under ss.32/33.
Sellers appealed; Divisional Bench (Chainani CJ and S.T. Desai J., April 28, 1959) remanded for decision on validity under s.20(3).
On remand, buyers' fourth affidavit (Nov 16, 1959) claimed s.20 inapplicable due to statutory Bye-laws under Forward Contracts Regulation Act and inconsistency.
K.T. Desai J. (Nov 26-27, 1959) dismissed petition, holding s.20 inapplicable as no power under s.20(4); no FERA infringement but partial contravention of Import Control; not void for vagueness.
Sellers appealed, buyers cross-objected; Tarkunde and Chitale JJ. allowed appeal, dismissed cross-objections, held s.20 maintainable, ordered costs to sellers.
Buyers appealed to Supreme Court with certificate.

legal_issues.text: Whether the contract is void for illegality under Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947 (s.5), Import Trade Control Act, due to clauses 6 and 7 requiring payments/acquisition in Africa.
Whether the contract is void for vagueness/uncertainty due to phrase 'subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause', lacking consensus ad idem.
Whether the amendment letter of Nov 30, 1957 is void for vagueness due to words 'if necessary'.
Whether petition under s.20 Arbitration Act maintainable given statutory Bye-law 38-A of East India Cotton Association, inconsistent with s.20(4).
Whether proper law governing contract is Indian law or law of British East Africa (lex loci solutionis).

petitioner_arguments.text: Clauses 6 and 7 breach s.5 FERA by envisaging payments, carry over charges, deficit on re-sale in Africa, and acquisition of property/foreign exchange abroad without RBI exemption.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act s.5(1)(e); s.21

petitioner_arguments.text: 'Subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause' vague, no consensus ad idem as multiple possible clauses.
Amendment letter 'if necessary' vague, no consensus.
S.20 inapplicable as Bye-law 38-A statutory under Forward Contracts Regulation Act, inconsistent with s.20(4), leaves no court power post-filing.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arbitration Act ss.20,46,47; Forward Contracts Regulation Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Proper law is lex loci solutionis (British East Africa) as performance there.

respondent_arguments.text: Contract saved by s.21 FERA implying term needing RBI permission; resale under Sale of Goods Act not as agent.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: FERA s.21(2),(3); Sale of Goods Act ss.54(2),(4)

respondent_arguments.text: 'Usual Force Majeure Clause' capable of being made certain by evidence of trade usage.
'If necessary' means if buyers fail to provide licence number, sellers extend discretionarily.
S.20 applicable; court files agreement, refers per Bye-laws; ss.46,47 save consistent provisions.

court_reasoning.text: Contract not void for FERA illegality as s.21(2) engrafts implied term requiring permission; s.21(3) allows proceedings but enforcement needs RBI nod; 'permission' covers s.5 prohibitions; resale not agency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: FERA does not arm against performance via illegality shield.

court_reasoning.text: 'Usual Force Majeure Clause' not vague; 'usual' refers to specific trade clause, capable of proof; distinguishes cases without 'usual'; commercial docs construed broadly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Capable of being made certain under s.29 Contract Act.

court_reasoning.text: 'If necessary' in amendment limits sellers' discretion under cl.6 if buyers delay licence; parties agreed, consensus exists.
S.20 maintainable: court decides validity/existence, files agreement, performs ministerial reference to Chairman per Bye-laws; ss.46,47 allow Bye-laws to prevail where inconsistent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Some Act provisions saved; Bye-laws govern procedure post-reference.

court_reasoning.text: Indian law governs: jurisdiction clause for Bombay High Court; arbitration in India imply Indian law.

holdings.text: Contract not void for illegality under FERA or import laws.
Contract not void for vagueness re Force Majeure clause.
Petition under s.20 maintainable despite Bye-laws.

precedents_cited.relevance: Force majeure conditions vague without 'usual'; here 'usual' specifies.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bishop Baxter Ld. v. Anglo-Eastern Trading Industrial Co. Ld.
precedents_cited.relevance: Usual terms in commercial docs susceptible to definite application.
Effort to give meaning to commercial agreements.

precedents_cited.case_name: Adamastos Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Construe commercial agreements broadly, not astute to find defects.

precedents_cited.case_name: N.V. Kwick Hoo Tong v. James Finlay Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Choice of forum implies choice of law.
Arbitration clause infers proper law even if void locally.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Maintainability of petition to file agreement and refer despite Bye-laws.

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Contract not invalid if permission required; implied terms; proceedings allowed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Agreements uncertain or incapable of being made certain are void; here capable.

statutes_cited.name: Sale of Goods Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Seller's resale with notice not as buyer's agent.

statutes_cited.name: Import Trade Control Act, 1947 / Import and Export Control Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Partial contravention possible but not wholly void.

statutes_cited.name: Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Bye-laws of East India Cotton Association statutory.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed. Supreme Court rejected all contentions, upheld High Court: contract valid, not void for illegality or vagueness; s.20 petition maintainable; Indian law governs. Matter to proceed to arbitration per Bye-law 38-A.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; arbitration to proceed.

key_quotes.text: The effect of these provisions is to prevent the very thing which is claimed here, namely, that the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act arms persons against performance of their contracts by setting up the shield of illegality.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on FERA s.21 saving contracts.

key_quotes.text: The use of the word 'usual' makes all the difference, and the meaning of the condition may be made certain by evidence about a force majeure clause, which was in contemplation of parties.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Resolves vagueness of force majeure clause.

key_quotes.text: So long as something is saved, it cannot be said that the Court after receiving the agreement and ordering that it be filed, becomes completely functus officio.
key_quotes.speaker: court
